reasoning: The question targets the paper’s core load-bearing premise (“mostly-great futures are a narrow/fragile target”), so a solid answer could substantially shift the paper’s optimism/pessimism about convergence vs compromise and the implied priority of interventions (high cruciality). It is strongly tied to this paper/series’ framing around ‘no easy eutopia’ and the island-target analogy (high paper-specificity). However, it bundles several hard-to-operationalise pieces (“measure/robustness” of high-value futures across models of value, feasibility constraints, and optimisation errors). Some progress is possible via formal modelling, sensitivity analyses over families of value functions, robustness to perturbations, and empirical/forecasting proxies about corrigibility and optimisation dynamics, but any “best-supported estimate” will remain model-dependent and speculative (moderate-low tractability). The core ask is understandable, but key terms (measure, high-value, plausible models, optimisation errors) are underspecified (moderate clarity). The strategic hinge is gestured at (wider target → less need for convergence/compromise; higher EV), but not articulated as crisp decision thresholds or alternative strategies (moderate decision hook). Most of the text contributes to motivation rather than clutter (low dead weight). Overall: important and paper-central, but limited by operational ambiguity and difficulty of producing a well-supported quantitative estimate.
title: Robustness of value targets under optimization error and value pluralism
